author: hgkamath
body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce



1. - login as unprivileged non-adminstrator user (or administrative user, does not matter, for administrative user UAC only warns without needing authentication )
2. - press windows start-key/click on windows start button
2. - start typing "power..."' or "pw..." . This switches the start menu to the type-to-search, which shortlists the powershell programs available in the startmenu/windows-system
3. - For each search-result found, the right-half-pane of the start menu, shows additional actions. Clicking on ">" sign of other "powershell versions" changes the right-half-pane to their additional actions.
4. - After choosing whichever powershell application, click on "Run as Administrator" action that shows up in the right-half-pane.
5. - UAC starts minimized (background), blinking orange on taskbar. IMHO the UAC should have foregrounded. This should happen only when background processes or not-in-focus applications request elevation. However, in this case the user is actively/intentfully starting an application.


Windows-10 ver 21H1, OS build 19043.1202
version of "windows powershell" : 5.1.19041.1202
version of "pwsh/powershell" 7.1.3 installed via chocolatey to C:\Program Files\PowerShell\7 (choco install powershell-core)
UAC level setting for ordinary user on highest 
UAC level setting for admin user is on second highest. 

Normally for most other apps, like cmd, cleanmgr, compmgmt, diskmgmt, the UAC dims screen and shows up in the foreground. One only needs to press Escape, or click-OK/press-spacebar to dismiss the UAC
The issue is, that for the above given procedure, one is forced to additionally click on orange blinking minimized UAC in taskbar to dismiss it.

Behavior/issue happens 
* ~~for "windows powershell", "windows powershell (x86)" and "Powershell 7 (x64)/pwsh"~~ [see comment](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/16053#issuecomment-913086154)
* when logged in as a ordinary non-administrative user or as user with administrative privileges

Behavior/Issue does not happen for the following cases
* ~~Does not happen for "powershell 7 preview (x64)" and "Windows Powershell ISE"~~ [see comment](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/16053#issuecomment-913086154)
* when "powershell" or "Windows powershell" is scrolled to in the start menu, right click, "run as administrator"
* when "windows powershell (Admin)" is started from right click of windows start button
* when "Open file location" is used to show shortcut locations in explorer, and run by "right click - run as administrator" .
* when "powershell exe" locations are located in windows-explorer and run by "right click - run as administrator"
In the above cases, UAC is foregrounded as expected.

It is somewhat disconcerting to move mouse to click on taskbar to maximize UAC just for powershell.

The question boils down to why does powershell elevated start behave differently when started it is started using windows-type-to-search.

### Expected behavior

```console
UAC should come in the foreground, dim rest of screen.
Should not start as orange blinking minimized UAC in taskbar .
One only needs to press Escape, or click-OK/press-spacebar to dismiss the UAC
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Starts as orange blinking minimized UAC in taskbar. One is forced to additionally click on orange blinking minimized UAC in taskbar to dismiss it.
```


### Error details

```console
NA
```

comments.author: hgkamath
comments.body:
okay, I noticed something. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3323558/132115457-b34619c0-2d7a-4957-a0dd-7630bea9de78.png)

In the right-side actions list, for every powershell version, there seems to be two "Run as A/administrator" actions
1) one with colored icon (also this has a capital A). "Run as Administrator" 
2) one with windows-standard outline icon. "Run as administrator" 
The first is the one that causes UAC to goto background
The second brings the UAC normally. 

The colored icon "Run as Administrator" shows up before pressing the "⌄" sign in the right hand pane which shows additional actions. In the image above the "⌄" has already been pressed and has turned into a "⌃" which is to hide the additional actions.

I think the colored icon "Run as Administrator" is populated as a form of quick-access action.

If this is correct, the workaround is to just avoid the attention grabbing colored icon "Run as Administrator" 
It is troublesome to ignore the quickly accessible one, click the "⌄" show more action sign each time to get to the right "Run as administrator" .

So in the original issue description, issue is not selective by powershell version. It happens for powershell versions (in my case, all versions) including the 'windows powershell ISE', which have this colored icon "Run as Administrator" quick-access-action. Strangely, for the 'Windows powershell ISE' the colored icon "Run as Administrator" does not appear in its own action list, but is appended to that of "Window powershell", which could be another bug.

Other applications when run as administrator, do not make this extra colored icon "Run as Administrator" .
I don't have any other app which has a colored icon "Run as Administrator" when they are type-to-search-ed to.

In the case of other application, rarely does the need arise to run then as administrator, so they do not require a quick-access action. Powershell is run as administrator frequently. So populating, 'Run as Administrator" as a quick-access action of the powershell app is a handy feature, only that it should not minimize the UAC.

So the question is who is authoring/registering/invoking those quick-access action?
powershell/ powershell installer/ powershell chocolatey installer/ windows-10 ?

I hope I am not jumping to hasty conclusion.

comments.author: hgkamath
comments.body:
As of 7.2.4, it still is.  Pressing the colored-in-icon-shortcuts, sends UAC-dialog to background as minimized yellow flashing icon on taskbar.

powershell-core is at version 7.2.4.  I have been upgrading through the minor versions through chocolatey ugrades, since last comment. Both it and the standard-powershell 5.1.19041.1682, have the double standard-outline-icon and the colored-in-icon-shortcuts. Win10 has also been getting its monthly patch Tuesday cumulatives and is now at 21H2 19044.1706 

I've sort of learned to ignore the colored-in-icon-shortcut and become habituated to extra the extra work of pressing the more-arrow ("⌄" sign) and choosing the outline-icon. The colored-in-icon-shortcut is always shown as a quick shortcut before the more-arrow press, though I am sure I click it much less.
Also, quick and preferable, is to press 'Win-x , a'  , this pops up the standard-powershell-5.1 into the foreground as expected.

Perhaps, a question to ask, is how those shortcuts got created. The answer to that might also explain why they look and behave differently . I wonder if those colored-in-icon-shortcuts are created on first run.

comments.body:
I uninstalled powershell-core-7.2.4 from the settings/apps&features. (did not reboot, nor relogin). Also did a ```choco-uninstall powershell-core``` for any cleanups.

Same behavior happens with shortcuts of win10 standard-powershell-5.1, (even without installing 7.2.4) with no other powershell-version installed

Can you confirm to me that the same behavior is seen by you? 

I reinstalled 7.2.4 ```choco install powershell-core```.
Upon this fresh-install, this time, for powershell-7.2.4, the ~~outline~~ colored-in-icon-shortcuts are not present in the menu. 
The ~~colored-in~~ outline-icon-shortcut is bringing the UAC dialog to the foreground as expected. 
I am not optimistic that this will prevail for long, at some point that ~~outline~~ colored-in-icon-shortcuts will get generated/populated in the menu and the troublesome behavior may re-appear.  ~~So, maybe, I think it happens when both types of shortcuts are present~~.  So, the blame squarely lies on those colored-in-shortcuts.

EDIT: some mistypes corrected above ( I misidentified the colored-in and outlined icon styles)
